sentences.sentence: NATO says it welcomes all peace initiatives, but Ukraine must have the final say.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: As leaders of China and Russia meet in Moscow for talks on Tuesday, NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg asks Beijing not to support Moscow's war in Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: JENS STOLTENBERG, NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg, NATO Secretary General China's peace proposal includes some positive aspects and elements which I support.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: For instance, the importance of nuclear safety, of protection of civilians and not least underlying the importance of sovereignty territorial integrity and independence and of course any peace solution for ukraine must be based on these principles nato says there's no proof that china is delivering lethal weapons to russia stoltenberg warns beij Beijing anyway against supplying them to the Kremlin.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: He also notes that the two countries are getting closer and closer.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: The meeting that takes place in Moscow is part of a pattern we have seen over the last years where China and Russia are coming closer and closer.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: We have to remember that just a couple of weeks or a few weeks before the invasion last February, President Xi and President Putin met in Beijing, where they signed a joint declaration promising each other a partnership without any limits.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Anger over France's pension reforms shows no signs of diminishing a day after the government survived two no-confidence votes over the issue.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: French residents in Paris bented their outrage over President Emmanuel Macron's use of a constitutional instrument to force the reform through Parliament, as our international correspondent Annelies Corges reports.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: correspondent Annelies Gorgias reports. Tensions remain high here in France, a day after the government of Emmanuel Macron narrowly survived a no-confidence vote in Parliament.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Protests broke out shortly after that vote and once again this Tuesday, people taking to the streets here in central Paris to demand that reform of the pension system to be scrapped.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: But beyond that, they say they're quite worried about the way things are done here in this country, the way Emmanuel Macron is governing France.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: The fact that the French president has adopted that special constitutional mechanism to bypass Congress and push through his reform, people here say, is undemocratic.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: They say he is a threat to French democracy and to French institutions. It's going to be very interesting to see what Emmanuel Macron has to say about that. He is set to finally break his silence this week in a televised interview on Wednesday. However, political analysts and a vast majority of the protesters here in Paris today say they don't expect any big announcements on Wednesday. They don't expect Emmanuel Macron to bow to popular pressure, at least not yet. And another day of national strike has been called for Thursday. Annelies Borges in Paris for Euronews.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: for Thursday. Annelies Borges in Paris for Euronews.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Britain's former Prime Minister Boris Johnson has admitted that he misled Parliament by telling MPs that parties at his Downing Street office did not break Covid lockdown rules.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: But in written evidence to a parliamentary committee, he insisted that he acted in good faith.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: in written evidence to a parliamentary committee, he insisted that he acted in good faith. Johnson was fined by police for breaking the Covid rules that his own government set. In his statement, the former Prime Minister said, I did not intentionally or recklessly mislead the House on the 1st of December 2021, the 8th of December or on any other date. I would never have dreamed of doing so. Johnson will appear in person before the committee on Wednesday. If it finds that he deliberately lied to the House of Commons, he could be suspended and ultimately face a by-election in his constituency in which he holds a slim majority of just over 7,000.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Johnson was forced out as Prime Minister after the latest in a series of scandals last July.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Marking World Water Day on March 22nd, the UN Children's Agency says 190 million children in 10 African countries are at the highest risk from a convergence of three water-related threats, inadequate water, sanitation and hygiene-related diseases.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Globally, more than 1,000 children under five die every day from water-related diseases, with around two out of five concentrated in these 10 African countries alone.
